title: Gamma Knife Radiosurgery for Metastatic Brain Tumors with Exophytic Hemorrhage
patient: A 63-year-old man with small-cell lung carcinoma presented with headache with dizziness. Brain MRI showed a metastatic brain tumor with hemorrhage (-). After waiting the patient’s stabilization for two weeks, GKS with a marginal dose of 25 Gy was performed with our radiosurgical technique (-). The measured hematoma volume and tumor volume were 12.15 cm3 and 7.10 cm3, respectively. On follow-up MRI at 3 months follow-up, the treated tumor was significantly regressed (-). After that, the tumor was disappeared for the following 6-month periods (-). However, the recurred tumor was detected in previously treated area of the solid tumor portion on the follow-up MRI at 11 monthsfollow-up (-). Consequently, he was re-treated with GKS for the recurred tumor.
